name: Garðskagi - Iceland's Twin Lighthouses
description: Garðskagi represents unique lighthouse complex featuring two distinct beacons separated by mere 50 meters creating architectural timeline where orange-and-white 1897 structure stands alongside taller 1944 World War II construction demonstrating evolving lighthouse technology and changing strategic priorities across nearly half-century spanning Iceland's transformation from Danish dependency to independent nation navigating global conflict's complexities. The old lighthouse constructed 1897 holds dual historical significance as Iceland's second-oldest lighthouse and nation's second-oldest concrete building, representing early adoption of modern construction materials in country where traditional turf and timber architecture dominated into 20th century—this technological innovation demonstrates how critical maritime infrastructure drove Iceland's modernization as fishing industry growth and international shipping connections demanded navigation aids matching European standards. The newer lighthouse erected 1944 during World War II reflects conflict's impact on neutral Iceland where Allied forces occupied country preventing German seizure and establishing Iceland as critical North Atlantic convoy protection base—lighthouse construction during wartime demonstrates how even neutral nations' infrastructure served Allied strategic interests as Iceland's geographic position controlling Denmark Strait and northern convoy routes made navigation improvements contribute indirectly to war effort despite Iceland maintaining official neutrality.
address: Garðskagi, Garður, Reykjanes Peninsula, Southwest Iceland
